column2: Reduce by at least 55% net GHG emissions compared to 1990 levels, by 2030.
column5: The implementation of TA1.3 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.9, as reducing GHG emissions will contribute to increasing the share of energy from renewable sources in the Union's gross final consumption of energy.

column2: Reduce methane emissions by 35 to 37% compared to 2005 levels, by 2030
column5: The reduction of methane emissions in TA1.7 will positively impact TA2.13, as it will contribute to the reduction of GHG intensity in the transport sector.

column2: The contribution of the sectors covered by the EU ETS with respect to the EU Climate ambition should be of -62 % compared to 2005
column5: The implementation of TA1.9 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.9, as the increased use of renewable energy sources will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions.

column2: ETS2: Contribution of the buildings and road transport sectors of 43% emission reductions by 2030 compared to 2005
column5: The implementation of TA1.10 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.9, as the reduction of emissions in the buildings and road transport sectors will contribute to the increase of the share of energy from renewable sources.

column2: Achieve an EU net greenhouse gas removal of 310 million tonnes CO2 equivalent per year for the land use, land use change and forestry (LULUCF) sector, by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA1.12 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.9, as the removal of GHG emissions will contribute to the reduction of net GHG emissions.

column2: No debit rule. For the period from 2021 to 2025, each Member State shall ensure that greenhouse gas emissions from the sector do not exceed greenhouse gas removals
column5: The implementation of TA1.13 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.9, as the no debit rule will ensure that the LULUCF sector does not contribute to an increase in net GHG emissions.

column2: Reduce buildings’ greenhouse gas emissions by 60%, by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA1.15 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.9, as the reduction of emissions in the buildings sector will contribute to the increase of the share of energy from renewable sources.

column2: REPowerEU sets a target of 10 million tonnes of domestic renewable hydrogen production and 10 million tonnes of renewable hydrogen imports by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.1 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.3, as the increased production and use of renewable hydrogen will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions.

column2: Set up at least one renewables-based energy community in every municipality with a population higher than 10,000 by 2025
column5: The implementation of TA2.2 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.9, as the increased use of renewable energy sources will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions in the ETS sector.

column2: Member States shall ensure that the contribution of renewable fuels of non-biological origin used for final energy and non-energy purposes shall be at least 42% of the hydrogen used for final energy and non-energy purposes in industry by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.3 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.10, as the increased use of renewable fuels of non-biological origin will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings and road transport sectors.

column2: Double the current deployment rate of individual heat pumps, resulting in a cumulative 10 million units by 2027 and 30 million units by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.4 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.15, as the increased use of heat pumps will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings sector.

column2: Bring online over 320 GW of solar photovoltaic by 2025 and almost 600 GW by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.5 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.9, as the increased use of solar photovoltaic will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions in the ETS sector.

column2: Energy demand to be covered by solar heat and geothermal should at least triple
column5: The implementation of TA2.6 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.15, as the increased use of solar heat and geothermal will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings sector.

column2: Over this decade, the EU will need to install, on average, approximately 45 GW per year of PV to reach the share of 45% of energy coming from renewables set out in the REPowerEU Plan
column5: The implementation of TA2.7 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.9, as the increased use of PV will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions in the ETS sector.

column2: Member States shall collectively ensure that the share of energy from renewable sources in the Union’s gross final consumption of energy in 2030 is at least 42.5%
column5: The implementation of TA2.9 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.3, as the increased use of renewable energy sources will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions.

column2: Member States shall set an indicative target for innovative renewable energy technology of at least 5% of newly installed renewable energy capacity by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.10 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.9, as the increased use of innovative renewable energy technologies will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions in the ETS sector.

column2: By 31 December 2025, each Member State shall agree to establish a framework for cooperation on joint projects with one or more other Member States for the production of renewable energy
column5: The implementation of TA2.11 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.9, as the increased cooperation on joint projects will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions in the ETS sector.

column2: The amount of renewable fuels and renewable electricity supplied to the transport sector leads to a share of renewable energy within the final consumption of energy in the transport sector of at least 29% by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.13 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.7, as the increased use of renewable fuels and electricity will contribute to the reduction of methane emissions in the transport sector.

column2: Each Member State shall increase the share of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector by at least 0.8 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the period 2021 to 2025
column5: The implementation of TA2.14 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.15, as the increased use of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings sector.

column2: By 2022, achieve 18% of the total increase in the share of energy from renewable sources between that Member State’s binding 2020 national target, and its contribution to the 2030 target of the share of energy from renewable sources in gross final consumption of energy
column5: The implementation of TA2.15 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.9, as the increased use of renewable energy sources will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions in the ETS sector.

column2: Member States shall endeavour to increase the share of renewable sources in the amount of energy sources used for final energy and non-energy purposes in the industry sector by an indicative increase of at least 1.6 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the periods 2021 to 2025 and 2026 to 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.16 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.10, as the increased use of renewable energy sources in the industry sector will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings and road transport sectors.

column2: A target of 15% electricity interconnection for 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.17 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.9, as the increased interconnection will contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions in the ETS sector.

column2: Member States shall ensure that the total final energy consumption of all public bodies combined is reduced by at least 1.9% each year, when compared to 2021
column5: The implementation of TA2.21 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.15, as the reduced energy consumption will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings sector.

column2: Member States shall collectively ensure a reduction of energy consumption of at least 11.7% in 2030 compared to the projections of the 2020 EU Reference Scenario
column5: The implementation of TA2.22 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.15, as the reduced energy consumption will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings sector.

column2: Member States shall make efforts to collectively contribute to the indicative Union primary energy consumption target amounting to no more than 992.5 Mtoe in 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.23 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.15, as the reduced energy consumption will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings sector.

column2: Each Member State shall ensure that at least 3% of the total floor area of heated and/or cooled buildings is renovated each year to be transformed into at least nearly zero-energy buildings or zero-emission buildings
column5: The implementation of TA2.24 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.15, as the renovation of buildings will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings sector.

column2: Reduce buildings’ final energy consumption by 14%
column5: The implementation of TA2.25 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.15, as the reduced energy consumption will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings sector.

column2: At least double the annual energy renovation rate of residential and non-residential buildings by 2030 and to foster deep energy renovations
column5: The implementation of TA2.26 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.15, as the increased renovation rate will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings sector.

column2: Reduce buildings’ energy consumption for heating and cooling by 18% compared to 2015 levels by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.28 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.15, as the reduced energy consumption will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings sector.

column2: Member states will have to renovate 16% of worst-performing non-residential buildings by 2030 and, by 2033, the worst-performing 26% through minimum energy performance requirements
column5: The implementation of TA2.29 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.15, as the renovation of worst-performing buildings will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings sector.

column2: The national measures will have to ensure that at least 55% of the decrease of the average primary energy use is achieved through the renovation of the worst-performing buildings
column5: The implementation of TA2.33 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.15, as the renovation of worst-performing buildings will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings sector.

column2: Member States shall ensure that the average primary energy use of the entire residential building stock decreases by at least 16% compared to 2020 by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.34 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.15, as the reduced energy consumption will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings sector.

column2: Member States are required to achieve cumulative end-use energy savings from 2021 to 2030, equivalent to new annual savings of at least 0.8% of final energy consumption in 2021-2023, at least 1.3% in 2024-2025, 1.5% in 2026-2027 and 1.9% in 2028-2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.41 is likely to have a positive impact on TA1.15, as the increased energy savings will contribute to the reduction of emissions in the buildings sector.
